awd_titl_txt: RAPID:  Population viability below the quasi-extinction threshold
awd_abstract_narration:
From time to time, formerly widespread species have declined to extinction. For example, passenger pigeons were once abundant throughout North America, but no longer exist. We often know about the factors that cause a widespread species to decline (in the case of the passenger pigeon, the original cause was hunting), but we know much less about what causes some populations to recover, and others not to do so, once that original cause of declines is gone. Monarch butterfly populations have declined dramatically in North America, and now western populations may be approaching extinction. In the 1980?s, millions of monarch butterflies overwintered on the California coast, and bred during the summer west of the Rocky Mountains. By the 2000?s, the overwintering population had declined to ~200,000-300,000 butterflies. In 2018, the population dropped to ~30,000 butterflies. This RAPID project will use the unexpected, rapid decline of western monarch butterflies to test theories of extinction risk. We will evaluate what changes in this suddenly-small population, through a combination of carefully controlled experiments and sightings reported by volunteers looking for monarch butterflies throughout the west, especially in California. We will use this knowledge to help guide management and recovery of this iconic butterfly population.

The research will test the hypothesis that vital rates, like survival and reproduction, decline as populations become very small, perhaps because individual animals have difficulty finding mates, or cannot protect themselves from predators as well as they could in groups. If very small populations decline due to these "Allee effects", there is a fleeting window of time in which to study population dynamics before local population extinction. Because we know so little about suddenly-small populations, ecologists typically base conservation plans on predicting declines to a ?quasi-extinction threshold?, in other words, a population size below which the species is unlikely to be able to recover. Based upon estimates of survival on overwintering grounds and reproduction in early spring, earlier work warned that 30,000 butterflies may be a quasi-extinction threshold for western monarchs. This project will (1) Test whether winter survival and spring reproduction are now lower than they were in the past; (2) Calculate rates of summer range expansion, and compare 2019 to years in the recent past, to evaluate potential reductions of survival, reproduction, or movement at other life stages; (3) Combine results of (1) & (2) with existing data to model dynamics of this migratory population through its full annual cycle. This model will be used to calculate annual population growth rates in small and large populations, and also to evaluate the potential of different management strategies to help western monarch butterflies recover from quasi-extinction.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When populations of plants and animals become very small, there can be additional knock-on problems that doom them to extinction.  For example, it may be more difficult to find mates or overcome predators.  These problems, known as Allee effects, have been widely explored in theoretical models, but only rarely documented in natural plant and animal populations.  One reason why Allee effects are hard to test in the wild is because, if Allee effects occur, there is only a small window in time between when a population crosses the threshold for Allee effects to happen and when the population goes extinct.

 

This project was a response to a sudden crash in abundance of monarch butterflies in the western United States.  Western monarch butterflies spend the winter clustering in forests along the California coast and expand into the interior west during summer breeding.  Estimates of the number of overwintering monarch butterflies on the California coast were in the millions in the 1980’s, a few hundred thousand in the first decades of the 21st century, and dropped from 200,000 in the winter of 2017-28 to about 28,000 in the winter of 2018-19.  We had previously estimated that a drop below 30,000 overwintering monarch butterflies would cross the threshold for Allee effects. 

 

With this award, we tested whether the survival, body size, or reproductive potential of western monarch butterflies was lower in the winter of 2018-19, compared to previous studies.  Contrary to our expectations, none of these rates were lower at overwintering sites in 2019, compared to the recent past (late 20th and early 21st century).  However, we found that winter survival is lower now than it was in the mid 20th century.  Therefore, although populations are not experiencing Allee effects, reduced overwinter survival may be a reason why the population in declining.  Protection and management of coastal overwintering sites is a high priority for conservation and restoration of western monarch populations.

 

As part of this award, we also built population models to inform conservation of monarch butterflies in the West.  These models led to two important insights: First, although western monarch butterflies expand inland as far as the Rocky Mountains during summer, the regions just inland from the overwintering sites are disproportionately important for population viability.  Protecting and restoring monarch habitat in the California Coast Range and Central Valley is a high priority for conservation.  Second, milkweeds, the plants monarch butterflies eat as caterpillars, are sparse enough in the West that monarch butterfly populations are probably limited by the amount of time they spend searching for habitat.  Search time limitation means that milkweed plants can limit monarch populations even though many plants do not get eaten, and that a one-time milkweed density can lead to persistent declines in monarch butterflies.  These expectations differ from a common assumption that if milkweed plants limit monarch butterflies, then both species should be changing in abundance at the same time.

 

The last part of this project was creation of the Western Monarch Mystery Challenge, an outreach program aimed at increasing knowledge of how monarch butterflies use the landscape in early spring.  This project engaged hundreds of community scientists to report monarch butterfly sightings in spring, including development of educational materials in English and Spanish related to the Mystery Challenge.  It also led to hundreds of additional observations that were contributed to public data bases like iNaturalist and the Xerces Society’s Western Monarch and Milkweed Mapper.  Furthermore, data from the Mystery Challenge led to two significant scientific insights.  First, we learned that western monarch butterflies expanded more slowly into their summer breeding range during the years when populations were very small.  These effects persisted through 2021.  Second, we learned that a non-migratory, year-round resident population of monarch butterflies has recently arisen in urban lands in the San Francisco Bay area.  The causes and consequences of both of these changes are unknown, and are important areas for future research.  Both changes also highlight the importance of expecting surprising and unpredictable changes when populations encounter new conditions, including unprecedentedly low population size as well as changing climate and landscape conditions.
